description: Borrowed from Latin elicitus from eliciō (“draw forth”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Elicited; drawn out; made real; open; evident.

verbs.description: elicit (third-person singular simple present elicits, present participle eliciting, simple past and past participle elicited)

entries.meaning: To evoke, educe (emotions, feelings, responses, etc.); to generate, obtain, or provoke as a response or answer.
To draw out, bring out, bring forth (something latent); to obtain information from someone or something.
examples: Fred wished to elicit the time of the meeting from Jane.

entries.meaning: To use logic to arrive at truth; to derive by reason
